    Inverts a value to place it at the opposite end of the curve's range (e.g., if the curve has a range from 0 - 1, calling InvertValue(0.8) will return 0.2).

    Sets the value of the first control point (applicable to both cubic and quadratic curves).
    void SetControlPoint1EditType​(VoltageCurve.ControlPt1EditType editMethod)
    Set the curve's editing method: BothXAndYEditable (users can edit both x and y components of control points), XMirrorsY (users can only edit the y component, and the x component will match it - only applicable to quadratic curves), YMirrorsX (users can only edit the x component, and the y component will match it - only applicable to quadratic curves).

    • SetHasRoundedCorners

      public void SetHasRoundedCorners​(boolean roundedCorners)
      If set to true, the edges of the curve object's bounding rectangle will have rounded corners Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      roundedCorners - true for rounded corners, false for square corners

    • SetRange

      public void SetRange​(float min, float max)
      Sets the curve's range. You can set the curve's start, end, and control point values to any value within the range. Defaults to min = 0 and max = 1. max must be > min. Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      min - the minimum range value
      max - the maximum range value

    • SetStartValue

      public void SetStartValue​(float val)
      Sets the y value (x value for non-horizontal curves) of the curve's starting position Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      val - the starting value. Must be within the curve's range.

    • SetEndValue

      public void SetEndValue​(float val)
      Sets the y value (x value for non-horizontal curves) of the curve's ending position Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      val - the ending value. Must be within the curve's range.

    • SetHorizontal

      public void SetHorizontal​(boolean bHorz)
      Set to true for a horizontal curve (the default) that proceeds left to right; set false to rotate the curve 90 degrees clockwise so that it proceeds top to bottom Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      bHorz - set true for a horizontal curve, false for a vertical one

    • SetCurveType

      public void SetCurveType​(VoltageCurve.CurveType newCurveType)
      Set the curve type: quadratic (which has 1 control point) or cubic (which has 2 control points) Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      newCurveType - the curve type

    • SetControlPoint1EditType

      public void SetControlPoint1EditType​(VoltageCurve.ControlPt1EditType editMethod)
      Set the curve's editing method: BothXAndYEditable (users can edit both x and y components of control points), XMirrorsY (users can only edit the y component, and the x component will match it - only applicable to quadratic curves), YMirrorsX (users can only edit the x component, and the y component will match it - only applicable to quadratic curves). Ignored if the curve itself isn't set as editable. Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      editMethod - the new editing method

    • GetControlPoint1EditType

      public VoltageCurve.ControlPt1EditType GetControlPoint1EditType()
      Gets the curve-editing type (both x & y components of control points editable; only x editable; only y editable). Not applicable for cubic curves or curves that aren't set as editable.
      Returns:
      the curve-editing method

    • SetControlPoint1

      public void SetControlPoint1​(float x, float y)
      Sets the value of the first control point (applicable to both cubic and quadratic curves). Values will be truncated to the curve's range min/max. Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      x - the x component of the control point
      y - the y component of the control point

    • GetControlPoint1

      public java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float GetControlPoint1()
      Returns the x & y components of the curve's first control point (applicable to both cubic and quadratic curves). Import java.awt.geom.Point2D.
      Returns:
      a Point2D.Float object containing the control point's coordinates

    • SetControlPoint2

      public void SetControlPoint2​(float x, float y)
      Sets the value of the second control point (only applicable to cubic curves). Values will be truncated to the curve's range min/max. Includes a call to a native function, so to conserve CPU, avoid regularly calling this function from ProcessSample().
      Parameters:
      x - the x component of the control point
      y - the y component of the control point

    • GetControlPoint2

      public java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float GetControlPoint2()
      Returns the x & y components of the curve's second control point (only applicable to cubic curves). Import java.awt.geom.Point2D.
      Returns:
      a Point2D.Float object containing the control point's coordinates

    • GetCurvePosition

      public java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float GetCurvePosition​(float pctDone)
      Gets the curve's location, in pixels, at a location 'pctDone' percent along the curve's length. Assumes a horizontal curve, so if your curve is vertical, you may need to convert the x value to InvertValue(y) and the y value to x. Import java.awt.geom.Point2D.
      Parameters:
      pctDone - how far along the curve's length to retrieve a position, from 0 - 1.
      Returns:
      a Point2D.Float object containing the curve's coordinates

    • GetCurvePositionNormalized

      public java.awt.geom.Point2D.Float GetCurvePositionNormalized​(float pctDone)
      Gets the curve's position, in a range from 0 - 1, at a location 'pctDone' percent along the curve's length. Import java.awt.geom.Point2D.
      Parameters:
      pctDone - how far along the curve's length to retrieve a position, from 0 - 1.
      Returns:
      a Point2D.Float object containing the curve's position

    • InvertValue

      public float InvertValue​(float val)
      Inverts a value to place it at the opposite end of the curve's range (e.g., if the curve has a range from 0 - 1, calling InvertValue(0.8) will return 0.2). Doesn't do any error checking to ensure that the input value is within the curve's valid range.
      Parameters:
      val - the value to invert
      Returns:
      the inverted value
